metadata.title: Notes on the genus Pulsatilla (Ranunculaceae) in Kosovo – Southeast Europe
metadata.description:
Background and aims – The genus Pulsatilla (Ranunculaceae) comprises ecologically and biogeographically significant taxa in the mountainous regions of the Balkans. Despite its importance, the diversity and distribution of Pulsatilla taxa in Kosovo have remained poorly documented. This study provides an updated overview based on new field data and critical taxonomic assessment.

Material and methods – Extensive fieldwork was carried out across various mountain massifs in Kosovo, supplemented by herbarium revisions and morphological comparisons with reference material. Elevational ranges, ecological preferences, and population data were recorded for each taxon.

Key results – A total of four species comprising five taxa are confirmed for the flora of Kosovo: Pulsatilla alpina subsp. apiifolia, P. halleri subsp. rhodopaea, P. montana subsp. balkana, P. montana subsp. jankae, and P. vernalis. New distributional records are provided, including the first confirmed presence of P. halleri subsp. rhodopaea in Kosovo and P. vernalis in the Sharri Mountains. Past misidentifications of P. montana subsp. jankae as P. vulgaris subsp. grandis are corrected. Conservation assessments suggest that P. alpina subsp. apiifolia remains nationally endangered, while P. halleri subsp. rhodopaea qualifies as Vulnerable due to its restricted range and occurrence at only two sites.

Conclusion – The study clarifies the taxonomy, distribution, and conservation status of Pulsatilla taxa in Kosovo. It highlights the regional importance of certain populations and underscores the need for continued monitoring and habitat protection in light of environmental pressures and climate change. These findings contribute to the broader understanding of plant diversity in the Western Balkans and support evidence-based conservation planning.

metadata.title: An enhanced qPCR method for rapid Agrilus planipennis detection and monitoring
metadata.description: Emerald ash borer (EAB; Agrilus planipennis) represents a serious threat to North American and European ash species (Fraxinus spp.). Spread of EAB westwards, from European Russia and Eastern Ukraine, could lead to dramatic consequences for native European ash populations. Early detection is essential for fast and successful eradication of new populations. In this study, we developed a new TaqMan qPCR assay allowing for sensitive and specific detection of EAB. We tested the specificity of the assay against 17 European Agrilus spp., eight buprestid species and nine species belonging to other wood-associated beetle taxa. The qPCR assay provided reliable amplification from samples with DNA concentrations as low as 0.5 picograms per reaction. Moreover, DNA could be amplified from different sample types, such as egg casings, leaves, faeces and bore dust from larval galleries. Robustness of the assay was verified by performing a blind test with four different laboratories. Here we provide a highly specific, robust and sensitive assay which can be used for enhanced surveillance of Agrilus planipennis on the European continent.

metadata.title: Socio-Psychological Dilemmas Across Time: Insights into Support, Identity, and Mental Well-being
metadata.description:
Abstract

 

This dissertation looks into how issues of support and personal identity have changed over time, and it links those shifts to mental health across different groups and eras. It starts by asking a simple question: how do massive social changes steer our inner lives? To figure that out, the study blends methods—mixing personal stories with hard numbers—to pull together snippets of experience, support, and the way people see themselves. Generally, the findings suggest that when cultural norms and political sentiments shift, people's sense of belonging and support networks also tend to change. Generally, stronger social ties and a positive self-image enhance mental resilience, while the absence of these elements can lead to feelings of isolation and worry. These results suggest that mental health programs should be adaptable to the shifting societal norms and individual needs. This work, by emphasizing the historical and contextual layers surrounding identity and support, also encourages healthcare providers to consider responsive strategies that are not universally applicable. All in all, policymakers and healthcare providers should really work on building communities that offer strong support and inclusiveness, helping all kinds of people secure better mental health outcomes.

 

The fabric of human life embroiders an intricate dance of togetherness and loneliness, a contradictory waltz of friendship and loneliness. At the center of this intricate ballet lies social psychological domain that throughout history sought to unravel the mystery of human interconnection. From the philosophical murmurs of Aristotle about humanity's web of shared being to the modern-day explorations of the maze of cognitive biases and the tapestry of social identity, the transformation of this field has been shaped by a world that is in continuous movement. With the unrolling of the tapestry of history, the burden of psychological shadows becomes heavier, interwoven with the complex patterns of our continuously changing society. We are at a crossroads today, where the fabric of human bonding is being stitched anew, often in ways that challenge our long-standing desire for belonging. This inquiry navigates the fabric of time, stitching together the threads of socio-psychological conundrums while shining a light on the invisible costs that emerge from the imbalanced scales of social support.

 

Across the canvas of history, social psychology has sewn its fabric into the texture of conformity, group dynamics, and the beautiful dance of identity formation, every strand a living stitch in the vast tapestry of cultures and civilizations. The rich tapestry of social solidarity, sewn by the very hands of giants such as Durkheim and Mead, displays the depth of human connections in tending the garden of psychological health. However, the past century has unfolded a canvas of change in the dance of human interaction, interwoven with the threads of globalization, the sparks of innovations in technology, and the stormy waves of socio- political turmoil. These changes have given rise to an array of complex socio-psychological enigmas in this new era. In a world where pixels twirl and screens glimmer, the boundaries that once characterized our physical attachments have dissolved into a hazy mist, building a mirage of limitless oneness, even as the loneliness of the heart becomes increasingly deep.

Those that were once alive with bridges spanning hearts and minds have become raging battlefields, where the collisions of beliefs reverberate boisterously, widening chasms and shredding the tender fibers of trust that once held us together. The widening gap between the false promise of companionship and the true state of connection has brought about an influx of emotional angst, with isolation seeping in like a stealthy storm. Research reveals that those who are riding the stormy seas of social support, whether through the burden of dependency, the darkness of neglect, or the lopsided currents of emotional investment—tend to be lost in a sea of increased stress, anxiety, and the turbulent aftereffects on their physical health. This fascinating phenomenon plays out dramatically on the canvas of relationships and the varied range of ages, as brought to light in this study. As we gaze over the horizon, social psychology's landscape is prepared to undergo an extraordinary overhaul. The rapid arrival of artificial intelligence and virtual companionship invites a tidal wave of profound questions: Will the fabric of human relationships come undone, making way for the glittering strands of AI-generated empathy and the subtle patterns of algorithmic companionship? Can virtual avatars ever craft the rich tapestry of human connection in all its deep shades?

 

Will groups weave genuine connections through meticulous policies, or will spirits roam a vast and uncharted territory on their own? These are the searing questions that call out for urgent mental investigation. Crossing disparate domains of knowledge will be the solution to unraveling answers to these developing mysteries. The fields of neuroscience, behavioral economics, and computational social science need to intersect like threads in a tapestry, intertwining knowledge that can bridge the growing gap of social inequality. Policymakers need to interweave frameworks that foster harmonious social support systems, protecting people from the heavy shroud of emotional isolation in an era characterized by the rapid currents of technological progress. The terrain of mental health needs to change, interlacing the strands of our online relationships into the tapestry of traditional healing arts, mirroring the constantly changing tapestry of human relationships.

 

By interlacing the strands of socio-psychological challenges from their earliest beginnings to their present- day complexities and the vague paths yet to come, this journey attempts to shed light on the constantly changing tapestry of human connection. As we stand at the precipice of a revolutionary social terrain, one inescapable truth remains: the human desire for connection is as vital as the air that we breathe into our lungs. Without a solid framework of support, even the greatest minds can falter, and the very fabric of our shared humanity can start to unravel. Therefore, it becomes crucial for us to not only observe these changes but also actively shape the fundamental essence of human relationships before they unravel like sand.

 

Support and identity issues have clearly evolved, and this study digs into how these shifting dilemmas influence mental well-being. At its core, it looks at the link between changing social landscapes and individual psychological outcomes. In most cases, the work involves gathering both qualitative stories and quantitative data on personal experiences, how people lean on support systems, and the varying ways they see

themselves—all across different groups and historical moments. Generally speaking, the study blends these elements in a way that feels both detailed and refreshingly unpredictable.
keywords: Social support, personal identity, mental well-being, socio-psychological dilemmas, cultural shifts, marginalized communities, resilience, globalization, digital communication, intersectionality

metadata.title: The Nociceptive Singularity: A Theory of Pain as an Information-Driven Phase Transition in a Critical System
metadata.description: Existing models of pain perception, from classical specificity theories to the more nuanced Gate Control Theory, predominantly conceptualize nociceptive signals as analog, intensity-graded inputs processed by the central nervous system. This framework, while foundational, struggles to fully account for the profoundly subjective, context-dependent, and often dichotomous nature of pain, particularly the abrupt, non-linear transition from manageable discomfort to overwhelming, all-consuming pain states.1 This paper introduces the "Nociceptive Singularity" theory, a novel framework that reframes nociception from a signal-intensity paradigm to an event-driven, information-processing paradigm. We posit that the initial afferent signal from a noxious stimulus is best modeled not as a dimensional quantity but as a zero-dimensional information event, signifying only the occurrence of a biologically salient perturbation.3 This dimensionless event acts as a critical perturbation on the brain's neural network, which, according to the Critical Brain Hypothesis, is maintained in a state of self-organized criticality (SOC).6 This perturbation triggers a cascade of neural activity known as a neuronal avalanche, a hallmark of information propagation in critical systems.9 The subjective experience of pain—its quality, location, and emotional valence—is not encoded in the initial input but is an emergent property of the spatiotemporal dynamics of this system-wide avalanche. This coherent, large-scale brain state constitutes the "nociceptive singularity," a concept that aligns with neuropsychological models of unified consciousness, or the "sense of singularity".12 This theory offers a unified framework that integrates principles from information theory, statistical physics, and neuroscience, providing novel explanations for the complex nature of pain and its modulation, and drawing compelling parallels to other cognitive phase transitions, such as the "Aha!" moment of insight.15

metadata.title: A TRANSITIVITY ANALYSIS OF PRESIDENT AQUINO'S INTERNATIONAL NEWS INTERVIEW ON THE TYPHOON YOLANDA DISASTER
metadata.description: The late former Philippine president Benigno Simeon C. Aquino III has been known for his diplomatic, cordial demeanor and deliberate explanation of issues whenever he would speak either in front of audiences as guest speaker or on television and/or radio as an interviewee. He is also remembered for his straightforward and deliberate yet polite replies as well as his wry humor, which he would deliver in Filipino especially when interacting with audiences who are composed of either civil servants or the general public. The study explored the various transitivity processes in the context of his worldwide interview with renowned British-Iranian broadcast journalist Christiane Amanpour, which focused on the effects of Typhoon Yolanda and the government’s disaster response. The interview was part of Ms. Amanpour’s program on the international edition of Cable News Network (CNN). Ramos utilized as his theoretical framework the Transitivity Analysis Theory by Halliday (in Halliday & Matthiesen, 2014). The overall results of the research revealed that material and relational processes were the most prevalent of all transitivity processes. In terms of personality and ideology, it was revealed that President Aquino reflected inclusivity and forthrightness as two of his dominant characteristics.  The current study recommends that political interviews in the vernacular be utilized for further research on transitivity analysis and that a series of broadcasted interviews by the same president or other contemporary presidents serve as data to determine patterns in terms of transitivity processes as well as indicators of personality and political ideologies.

metadata.title: STANDARDIZATION AND OPTIMIZATION OF A POETRY BY INTERPRETATION AND EXPLORATION
metadata.description:
*Refining Poetry for Maximum Impact*

To create a powerful and engaging poem, poets can use standardization and optimization techniques. These involve refining the poem's form, language, and structure to convey its message effectively.

*Key Aspects:*

- *Consistency:* Ensure consistency in form, language, and tone to create a cohesive poem.
- *Effective Language:* Choose precise and evocative words to engage the reader.
- *Structure:* Use line breaks and stanza structure to control the poem's flow and tension.
- *Sound and Rhythm:* Employ sound devices to create a musical quality.
- *Emotional Resonance:* Craft the poem to evoke a specific emotional response.

*Goals:*

- *Enhance Impact:* Make the poem more effective in conveying its message.
- *Improve Reader Experience:* Create an engaging and enjoyable reading experience.
- *Increase Memorability:* Make the poem more memorable and quotable.

*Techniques:*

- *Revision and Editing:* Refine the poem through review and revision.
- *Feedback:* Seek feedback to identify areas for improvement.
- *Poetic Devices:* Use devices like metaphor and simile to add depth and complexity.
- *Experimentation:* Try different forms and structures to find the most effective approach.

By refining their poetry, poets can create a more impactful and engaging work that resonates with readers.

creators.name: Venkatesan
creators.affiliation: University of Messina

references: https://doi.org/10.53555/kuey.v30i6.9230
metadata.method:
Conclusion:

Standardization and optimization of poetry refer to the process of refining and enhancing a poem to make it more effective, engaging, and impactful. This can involve various techniques, such as:

*Standardization:*

1. *Consistency in form and structure:* Ensuring that the poem follows a consistent rhyme scheme, meter, or stanza structure.
2. *Language and tone:* Using language and tone that is consistent with the poem's theme and style.
3. *Imagery and symbolism:* Using imagery and symbolism that is consistent and effective in conveying the poem's meaning.

*Optimization:*

1. *Word choice and phrasing:* Selecting words and phrases that are precise, evocative, and engaging.
2. *Line breaks and stanza structure:* Using line breaks and stanza structure to create a sense of flow, tension, and drama.
3. *Sound and rhythm:* Using sound devices such as alliteration, assonance, and consonance to create a musical quality.
4. *Emotional resonance:* Crafting the poem to evoke a specific emotional response or connection with the reader.
5. *Clarity and concision:* Ensuring that the poem's meaning is clear and concise, without unnecessary complexity or ambiguity.

*Goals of Standardization and Optimization:*

1. *Enhance the poem's impact:* Make the poem more effective in conveying its message or theme.
2. *Improve the reader's experience:* Create a more engaging and enjoyable reading experience.
3. *Increase the poem's memorability:* Make the poem more memorable and quotable.

*Techniques for Standardization and Optimization:*

1. *Revision and editing:* Reviewing and revising the poem to ensure that it meets the desired standards.
2. *Feedback and critique:* Seeking feedback from others to identify areas for improvement.
3. *Poetic devices:* Using poetic devices such as metaphor, simile, and personification to add depth and complexity to the poem.
4. *Experimentation:* Trying out different forms, structures, and language to find the most effective approach.

By standardizing and optimizing a poem, poets can create a more effective, engaging, and impactful work that resonates with readers.

metadata.title: Invasive signal crayfish and native noble crayfish show trophic niche shrinkage in sympatry
metadata.description: Studying the coexistence of native species and invasive species with similar functional traits, habitat usage, and feeding habits is crucial for understanding the dynamics of invasion and ecological changes in the invaded ecosystem. Due to competitive exclusion and often also dissemination of crayfish plague pathogen (Aphanomyces astaci, Schikora), North American crayfish represent a major threat to European native crayfish. Their co-occurrence is often only temporary, making studies investigating trophic ecology of native and non-native crayfish species rare. In this study, trophic niche and feeding ecology of European native noble crayfish Astacus astacus (Linnaeus, 1758) and North American signal crayfish Pacifastacus leniusculus (Dana, 1852) were compared between their sympatric and allopatric sites, in Křesánovský brook (Czech Republic), using carbon and nitrogen stable isotopes analysis. The results indicated a substantial change of trophic niche and diet of noble crayfish between allopatry and sympatry. In allopatry, both juvenile and adult noble crayfish exhibited a wider trophic niche width compared to juvenile and adult signal crayfish. However, in sympatry, where adult and juvenile noble crayfish coexisted with signal crayfish, their trophic niche width significantly narrowed and their diet shifted towards a more plant-based one. High degree of trophic niche overlap was observed between adults and juveniles in both species, particularly in sympatry rather than in allopatry. The substantial trophic niche overlap and dietary similarity between native noble crayfish and invasive signal crayfish in sympatry, make their long term coexistence on the invaded site unlikely.
